The mathematical foundations of quantum theory have been a source of controversy for more than a century. The Copenhagen interpretation, which has been widely accepted, is based on a set of axioms that are not fully satisfactory. In this paper, we propose a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are sufficient to guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The axioms are also useful for studying the category of Hilbert spaces and continuous linear operators between them.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To gain insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the transcriptome and genome of two distantly related myxozoan species to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1 channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This will have severe consequences for global food security, especially for the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We quantify the magnitude of this yield variability and its consequences for global maize production and trade. We find that the probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Our results highlight the need for global food security strategies that include both adaptation and mitigation.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of COVID-19 on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they are pessimistic about accessing the CARES Act. We also conduct an experiment to understand the effects of loans versus grants on business resilience.

Reproductive output is a fundamental measure of fitness and is limited by maternal resources. All forms of provisioning and allocare increase maternal energy availability, but the extent to which this increases reproductive output is unknown. We show that all forms of provisioning and allocare increase reproductive output, but the extent to which this occurs is dependent on the form of provisioning. Allonursing is the most effective form of provisioning, increasing reproductive output by 30%. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of allonursing in mammals. Allonursing is a highly effective form of provisioning that should be considered when understanding the evolution of parental care.

Caspase-1 inhibition also protects neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that caspase-1 inhibition may be a promising therapeutic strategy to limit α-syn pathology in synucleinopathies including MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. Cell activities were cross-correlated and compared to a stochastic model to determine network connections. Highly correlated Ca2+ activities occurred in scattered cell clusters, and network communication links between them exhibited unexpectedly short path lengths. The number of connections between cells (degree distribution) followed a power-law relationship revealing a scale-free network topology. The path length and degree distribution revealed an endothelial network with a “small-world” configuration. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We present the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance data and many auxiliary signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for health. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the food ingested. The gut microbiome is also a reservoir for antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The gut microbiome is therefore a potential target for the development of new therapeutics. The gut microbiome is also a potential source of new natural products, which are compounds that are produced by living organisms and have a wide range of potential applications. Here, we report the discovery of natural products from anaerobic gut fungi that could be used as therapeutics. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize natural products. The discovery of natural products from anaerobic gut fungi could lead to the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the establishment of social hierarchies remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait known to influence social behavior, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is heterochronic, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed in the fetus and newborn and adult hemoglobin (HbA) being expressed in adults. The HbF/HbA ratio is a marker of fetal and neonatal hemoglobin expression. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is developmentally downregulated in human fetal liver and upregulated in adult bone marrow. IGF2BP1 overexpression in human erythroid cells causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This reversal is mediated by reduced expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. The HbF/HbA ratio may be a marker of fetal and neonatal hemoglobin expression. This study provides a mechanism for the HbF/HbA ratio to be a fetal and neonatal hemoglobin expression marker.

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying molecular mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are not fully understood. Here, we show that voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs) activate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote VSMC remodeling. LCCBs act on the STIM N terminus to cause STIM relocalization to junctions and subsequent ORAI activation in a Cav1.2-independent and store depletion-independent manner. LCCB-induced promotion of VSMC remodeling requires STIM1, which is up-regulated in VSMCs from hypertensive rats. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of heart failure. (Continued)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and maintaining older forests stabilized bird populations. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition, but the NWFP failed to halt declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP’s policy of maintaining older forests is still needed to stabilize populations of these species. The NWFP also failed to halt declines of early-seral–associated bird populations, which are still declining. The NWFP’s policy of maintaining early-seral ecosystems is needed to stabilize these populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings have implications for policy makers and forest managers worldwide.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented here is a promising approach for the rational design of new antibiotics. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for the problem of semantic segmentation of satellite images. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and circadian rhythms are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, whereas reading a printed book has no such effects. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. They also highlight the need for further research into the biological effects of these devices on sleep and circadian rhythms. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4–deficient mice developed lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of Foxp3+ Treg cells, but this was not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice had opposing impacts on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4 deficiency affected both central and peripheral tolerance, it was not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and 4,818 genes. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and estimated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, which is key to the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Our results suggest that these habits were driven by convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. The results also indicate that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Copyright © 2022. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits spread through a population and become more common over time. We conducted a large-scale experiment to investigate the extent to which larger populations enhance CCE. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that CCE was enhanced by the presence of social learning. These results have implications for the evolution of culture in human societies.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest solid body in the solar system. The core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase under the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the origin of the Earth's inner core. It also provides a general nucleation mechanism for the crystallization of iron-based alloys. This work is expected to be helpful for understanding the origin of other planets and stars. It also provides a new approach for studying the nucleation of other materials. The results are published in the journal Science Advances.

Marijuana legalization debates highlight the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. Specifically, compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated brain DA responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability (reflecting DA increases). In ventral striatum (key brain reward region), MP-induced reductions in DVs and BPND (reflecting DA increases) were inversely correlated with scores of negative emotionality, which were significantly higher for marijuana abusers than controls. In marijuana abusers, DA responses in ventral striatum were also inversely correlated with addiction severity and craving. The attenuated responses to MP are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for the design of future studies of the effects of marijuana on the brain. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predicting text can also predict neural responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that the neural correlates of language comprehension may be driven by the same, highly predictive processing in both humans and machines. We also find that model architecture is a strong predictor of neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism for language comprehension.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear why DL works so well. One of the most important reasons is that DL is a black box, and it is difficult to understand how it works. In this paper, we show that the black box of DL can be opened by introducing a new class of neural networks called stable neural networks. We prove that stable neural networks have universal approximation properties. Moreover, we prove that stable neural networks can be computed by an algorithm. This algorithm is fast and stable. We believe that this work will help us understand the black box of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. A classic experiment published in 1975, which was used to demonstrate the existence of a “planning fallacy” in humans, is cited as evidence for this phenomenon. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not recognized until 2020, when the pandemic was already well underway. This case study illustrates the dangers of uncritically accepting research findings as “truth” and the importance of rigorous scientific method.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae that affects the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the nose. The disease is curable with multidrug therapy, but the disease is still endemic in remote areas of the world. The causative agent of the noninfectious, noninflammatory, and nonpruritic reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, a condition that occurs in leprosy patients who have been cured for many years, is unknown. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, a leprosy pathogen that causes diffuse lepromatous leprosy, and found that it is closely related to M. leprae, the causative agent of leprosy. This finding suggests that the two leprosy bacilli have retained many of the same functions for survival for millions of years. The discovery of M. lepromatosis may also lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of leprosy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in the study of quantum quenches. However, an exact computation of the entanglement dynamics was available so far only for noninteracting systems, whereas it was deemed unfeasible for interacting ones. Here, we show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We thoroughly check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work provides a general framework for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also provides a new perspective on the entanglement–entropy connection.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. We describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at room temperature in hamsters. The vaccine is highly protective in hamsters, and a single dose is sufficient to protect against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C, making it suitable for mass vaccination programs. This vaccine has the potential to help combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using Bayesian inference to model complex epidemiological data. Our model can be used to study the historical spread of plague in Europe. The code is available at https://github.com/johan-van-der-meulen/Ectoparasite_Plague.git.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. We present a comprehensive analysis of neuron numbers in amniotes, which are the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess. Interestingly, relative brain size is associated with relative neuronal cell density in reptiles, birds, and primates but not in other mammals. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is known to sever actin filaments, but how it does so is not understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to actin filaments and displaces actin monomers, thereby depolymerizing the filament. However, we also find that ADF-induced filament depolymerization is enhanced by mechanical stress. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced mechanical torque enhances the depolymerization rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by ADF far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our work provides a general mechanism for how mechanical stress can enhance the activity of proteins involved in severing actin filaments. This mechanism may be relevant to many biological processes, including cytokinesis and cell migration. (Continued)

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess and is a major contributor to the epidemic of obesity and diabetes. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The greater brain activation to food cues may also promote feeding behavior. Our findings have implications for the development of novel strategies to reduce fructose consumption and its deleterious effects on health.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and cultural diversity. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and we used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across the island. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar. They also highlight the importance of sex-biased admixture and the heterogeneity of the settlement history of Madagascar. This study is also relevant to the study of the peopling of the Indian Ocean.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but controversial in real-world settings. We test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed of Facebook users. When positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social media platforms. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequence is modified in many ways, including the addition of a sugar modification called pseudouridine (Ψ). Ψ is the most common sugar modification in coding regions of mRNA, but its function in translation is unknown. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter translation speed and the decoding of a codon. Our work suggests that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA and that the presence of Ψ can have a small effect on translation. This study provides insight into how mRNA sequences can be modified to regulate translation. Our findings also have implications for the study of disease-causing mutations in the human genome. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, greater prosperity, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. Longitudinally over a 4-y period, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Aquatic mammals are larger than their terrestrial relatives, but the extent to which potential ecological, biomechanical, and physiological controls contribute to this pattern remains unclear. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that aquatic mammals are driven toward a size attractor and are confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This model provides a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is a common driver of body size increase.

The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C than at 33 °C in primary mouse airway epithelial cells. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway. Rhinovirus replication is associated with a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces on short timescales. This mechanosensory system requires type IV pili to be attached to a solid surface, followed by pili retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa uses type IV pili for both twitching motility and as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model of surface sensing may be relevant to other bacteria. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the consequences of pesticide exposure on aquatic biodiversity are still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to aquatic biodiversity. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies (>2,500 sites in 73 countries) that evaluates, for the first time to our knowledge on a global scale, the exposure of surface waters to particularly toxic agricultural insecticides. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a call for action.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillback to humans is a major public health concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. Deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and experimentally infected fawns can transmit the virus. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. A proactive “One Health” approach is needed to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to mitigate the risk of spillback to humans.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the livelihoods of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the environmental and social impacts, and the solutions. We propose that the industry needs to move away from building large dams and toward smaller, decentralized, renewable energy sources. We also propose that governments need to be more transparent and accountable in the decision-making process.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ oligomers, which are not normally found in the extracellular space, are the most toxic species within the brain. We demonstrate that Aβ oligomers are neurotoxic in a laser microdissected neuron model, which is devoid of extracellular Aβ pathologies. Moreover, we show that Aβ oligomers are capable of inducing a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which is associated with microglial activation. These findings suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for AD. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The method is based on the use of hydrogen exchange to probe the structure of the folded state and pulse labeling to follow the folding process. The first step is slow and involves the formation of a distinct intermediate that is an obligatory step on the folding pathway. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are thought to function as signaling molecules. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme ApaH removes the cap from RNAs, but in response to stress, the Np4-capped RNAs accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by stress, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. We demonstrate that RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapsulate other RNAs. The unusual manner in which Np4-capped RNAs bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. The differential impact of RppH on the rates at which capped and uncapped 5′ termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of immunosuppression, which is a major cause of poor clinical outcomes. We demonstrated that arginine, a major amino acid in the diet, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also showed that arginine supplementation is more efficient than citrulline supplementation in restoring the immune system during sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass is ≈2 orders of magnitude higher than the terrestrial biomass, and that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, where systems evolve in a self-sustaining manner, with no external control. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is a hallmark of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of plant-derived biofungicides. However, the mode of action of these peptides against plant fungal pathogens is largely unknown. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of plant-derived biofungicides. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. Although the male–female interface is well characterized, the extent to which the female contributes to the male’s reproductive success is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that female-derived proteins associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Our research provides a foundation for future studies aimed at understanding the extent to which the female contributes to the male’s reproductive success. © 2016.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied extensively. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study fills this gap, providing a database of over 45,000 unique human-associated virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. The database is used to uncover over 2,200 virus–disease associations. The database is freely available at https://www.humanmicrobiomeproject.org/virusdb/.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The HSRL was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing, China, to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI processes. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This study provides a new way to observe ACI. (Read more)

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from light-dependent organisms, which are shown to have evolved under temperatures consistent with a hot early Earth. This finding is consistent with both isotopic and protein reconstruction-based interpretations of the temperature history of the early Earth. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The Plasmodium parasite exploits the host erythrocyte to complete its life cycle, and invasion of the red cell is the first step in this process. The malaria parasite uses a number of adhesins to bind to the red cell surface, but the function of this interaction is unknown. Here, we show that binding of the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 to glycophorin A on the red cell surface leads to a change in the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte. This change in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion, suggesting that parasite-induced changes in the erythrocyte’s biophysical properties are important for invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on malaria parasite invasion and opens up new avenues for the development of antimalarial drugs. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and other applications. It has a bandgap of 5.5 eV, which is too small for many applications. We show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned continuously from indirect to direct. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond for applications. We also show that the bandgap can be stabilized against the instability to graphite by strain. This is important for applications. Our results are based on first-principles calculations and machine learning. They are validated by experiments. They are relevant for applications in the fields of quantum and nanoelectronics, photonics, and energy storage. They are also relevant for the general field of strain engineering of materials.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal increase in influenza virus transmission coincides with a decrease in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus transmission and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. © 2020 American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how the brain’s activity varies during the formation of phrase structure. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This merge operation applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the brainstem. We also show that this circuit is involved in promoting overeating and contributes to obesity. This circuit may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for plant growth. However, the nitrogenase enzyme, which catalyzes this process, is highly inefficient in the absence of oxygen. The ability to control the onset of nitrogen fixation in plants would allow for the efficient delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to the plant, thereby improving nitrogen use efficiency and crop productivity. Here, we demonstrate that rhizopine, a signaling molecule produced by plants, can control the expression of the nitrogenase enzyme in the nitrogen-fixing bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signaling molecule in other systems. This approach could be used to control the onset of nitrogen fixation in other nitrogen-fixing bacteria, such as rhizobia, which are the most important group of bacteria for N2 fixation in agriculture. The Peruvian Amazon is a global hotspot of deforestation and forest degradation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the effectiveness of these systems in the Peruvian Amazon is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their information is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that this is because crop experts’ information is not easily accessible and is not used in a way that is compatible with the information provided by other sources. We propose a framework that transforms the original categorical information provided by crop experts into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more compatible with quantitative analysis. We show that this probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate how this probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our framework can be used to improve the quality of crop monitoring systems in any country.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This is a fundamentally different approach to memory than the traditional view that relies on elevated firing rates or excitatory feedback. Our results suggest that memory is supported by a form of synaptic facilitation that reduces firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. Our findings provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (Continued)

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people do, in fact, react more strongly to negative news content, but that this negativity bias is not universal. Individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is also evident. These results help explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” They also highlight the importance of individual-level differences in responsiveness to news content.

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) signaling pathway is a major regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO signaling pathway, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates causes neuronal death. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on active release of aggregates from the cell of origin and uptake of aggregates by recipient neurons. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates may be a potential therapeutic strategy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is associated with the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that contain a variety of proteins, including those that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The oldest known aquatic angiosperms are from the Cretaceous period, more than 120 million y ago. The oldest known aquatic angiosperm from the Cretaceous is Montsechia vidalii, first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Montsechia is a small plant with a simple leafless stem and a single leaf-like structure. The plant is similar to Ceratophyllum, a modern aquatic plant that is sister to all other flowering plants. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase is greater for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by occupational changes or changes in the prevalence of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This regulation of the glycan catabolism is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. We propose that this strategy is widespread in nature and may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate effects on students of color and students from low-income families. Evaluated at five middle schools, the intervention halved year-long student suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. This suggests that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental impact of the food system. This is equivalent to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61% in a cafeteria with 25% vegetarian meals, and 79% in a cafeteria with 50% vegetarian meals. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. This approach could be used to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and land use change from the food system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented without significant adverse effects on electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 50 million confirmed cases and over 1.1 million deaths worldwide. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be involved in immune suppression. The structure also reveals a second interface that is not present in SARS-CoV, which may be involved in evasion of the host immune system. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that induces cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. Human-caused wildfires have become so common that they now account for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. The expansion of the fire niche has important implications for the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of those neighborhoods. This may have implications for urban planning and policy.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a new target for the development of natural repellents. Copyright © 2020. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of coral color and the bleaching of the reef. The underlying cause of bleaching is the overheating of zooxanthellae, which leads to their death. However, the consequences of this breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host is increased during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a tight barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the absence of tumor suppression, intestinal tumors lead to dysregulation of the intestinal barrier, which in turn promotes tumorigenesis. We show that the intestinal microbiome can trigger a regenerative response and stimulate tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our experiments highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate intestinal homeostasis and tumorigenesis. It also provides a model system to study the role of the microbiome in cancer. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. We found that breast cancer cells express the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1, which is up-regulated following chemotherapy. ROR1 expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important in regulating breast cancer stemness. ROR1 expression also enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series, with a ∼192-y eruption cycle, occurred exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly triggered a series of climate changes that extended from the Antarctic Peninsula to the subtropics. The timing of the Mount Takahe eruptions is consistent with a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which would have led to a rapid warming of the Southern Hemisphere and a cooling of the Arctic. The coincidence of the Mount Takahe eruptions with the start of accelerated deglaciation supports the hypothesis that the Southern Hemisphere was in a glacial-state climate for a long time before the start of deglaciation. This hypothesis is important for understanding the causes of the last glacial inception. The Mount Takahe eruptions are the only known volcanic eruptions that occurred during the last glacial period. Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Copyright © 2015. The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 is responsible for the high capacity and low potential. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized.
