The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In contrast, the mammalian CNS lacks the ability to regenerate after injury, and the ability to regenerate in the adult nervous system is limited to a few specific neuron types. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway and is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite. We also identify a form of regeneration in the mammalian CNS that is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. These findings suggest that the molecular mechanisms controlling regeneration in the adult nervous system are conserved. Moreover, they suggest that the regeneration we identify in C. elegans may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. This study also suggests that the mammalian CNS may have a greater regenerative capacity than previously thought. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we use a population genomic approach to identify the locations of these binding sites in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that the binding sites are distributed in a polarity-dependent manner, with the highest concentrations near the start of genes. This pattern is reminiscent of yeast and mouse models, suggesting that it may be a conserved eukaryotic mechanism. The polarity of the binding sites may be important for the initiation of recombination. The distribution of the binding sites may also be important for the maintenance of genome integrity. This study provides a detailed view of the distribution of recombination initiation sites in a flowering plant. It also provides a resource for future studies of the function of these sites. Resting state networks (RSNs) are a set of anatomically contiguous brain regions that are functionally connected in a coherent manner. RSNs have been identified by resting state fMRI, but their functional significance is still unclear. We used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. Network deactivation was reduced in early PD; this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from PD and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is essential for efficient translation and mRNA stability. The 5′ cap structure is also found on tRNA and rRNA. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNAs. We show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is not dependent on the presence of a 7-methylguanosine cap. The 5′ NAD+ cap is found on pre-messenger RNAs and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. The 5′ NAD+ cap structure may have a role in modulating mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. We compared DNA-me profiles in genomic DNA of whole blood (WB) isolated at Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) baseline from 32 cases (DCCT conventional therapy group subjects showing retinopathy or albuminuria progression by DCCT year 10) vs. 31 controls (DCCT intensive therapy group subjects without complication progression by DCCT year 10). Twelve annotated differentially methylated loci were common in both WB and Monos, including thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP), known to be associated with hyperglycemia and related complications. A set of differentially methylated loci depicted similar trends of associations with prior HbA1c in both WB and Monos. In vitro, high glucose induced similar persistent hypomethylation at TXNIP in cultured THP1 Monos. These results show that DNA-me differences during the DCCT persist at certain loci associated with glycemia for several years

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that is associated with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. © 2015 Federation of European Biochemical Societies. All rights reserved.

The tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) is a model system for studying plant–environment interactions and the evolution of complex traits. The fruit of the closely related species Solanum pennellii are nearly devoid of all nitrogenous volatiles, while the fruit of S. lycopersicum and S. pimpinellifolium accumulate high amounts. Using an introgression population derived from S. pennellii, we identified a locus essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of the underlying gene in transgenic plants abolished production of aliphatic and aromatic nitrogenous volatiles in ripe fruit, and metabolomic analysis of these fruit revealed the accumulation of 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid, a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. Biosynthetic incorporation of stable isotope-labeled precursors into 2-isobutylthiazole and 2-phenylacetonitrile confirmed that cysteine provides the nitrogen atom for all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. (Continued)

Global warming and biodiversity loss are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of biodiversity conservation and restoration strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record freely behaving mouse MEC activity in a large number of neurons. We found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial navigation, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells tend to intermingle. These results suggest that grid cells might form a distinct network from other cell types. This study provides a powerful method for studying the organization of the MEC. The freely behaving mouse model used here will be useful for studying the neural basis of navigation and other cognitive functions. The two-photon microscope used here will be useful for studying neural activity in freely behaving animals. The data generated here will be useful for developing computational models of the MEC. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by environmental and internal cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to function as an important interplant flowering signal, which is able to induce flowering in the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of flowering regulation in a host–parasite interaction. © 2014 American Society of Plant Biologists. All rights reserved.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The pathophysiology of the disease is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) and their replacement by glial cells. Here, we show that the dopamine-containing neurons in the SNc are not the sole source of dopamine in the striatum. Instead, we identify a previously unrecognized system of striatonigral fibers that originate in striosomes, a subregion of the SNc, and arborize in clusters around dopamine-containing dendrites in the SNc. These clusters are termed “striosome–dendron bouquets.” The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets may be important to understanding the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease. This work

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are composed of specialized cells that are unique in their electrophysiological properties. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SANCs by modulating the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry and the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Our results suggest that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Silicon (Si) is an essential micronutrient for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. Although Si has been shown to confer resistance against abiotic stresses, its role in mediating resistance against biotic stresses, including insect herbivory, has not been well documented. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by jasmonic acid (JA), a key signaling molecule in plant defense. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA signaling may be a promising strategy for developing insect-resistant rice. This study also provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of Si-mediated insect resistance. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This is a fundamentally different approach to memory than the traditional view that relies on elevated firing rates and excitatory feedback. Our results suggest that memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces firing rates and is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for both basic and applied research. Copyright © 2020. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Nutrient pollution from small watersheds is a growing concern for coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient loads is poorly understood. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all watersheds of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily N and P delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small watersheds exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Higher bioavailability of nutrients from small watersheds suggests greater potential to fuel algal blooms in coastal areas. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work highlights the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient loads. Our findings have implications for coastal managers and policy makers.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. We also find that the network’s response to environmental forcing is highly nonmonotonic, with a sharp peak in the rate of environmental forcing required to maintain the steady state. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” instability, which is another well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoimmune encephalitis that can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. However, the mechanisms by which NMDAR-Abs cause these paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic cortical microcircuitry to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be a useful model for studying the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in other autoimmune encephalitis. This may have implications for the development of new therapies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key driver of Earth system evolution and the origin of life. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a detailed analysis of a 300-million-year-old climate event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system. They also provide a potential mechanism for the origin of life. This work is important for understanding the history of abrupt climate change and the origin of life.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation. Rather, it is a tool that can be used to achieve other conservation and climate goals. Our findings highlight the importance of rigorous impact evaluations for sustainability certification. The RSPO has made significant progress in improving its standards, but more work is needed to achieve its goal of 100% certified sustainable palm oil by 2020.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Copyright © 2015. Sex determination is a fundamental evolutionary process that shapes the sex ratio, sex-specific phenotypes, and sex-specific behaviors of a species. In vertebrates, sex determination is often regulated by a single genetic locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple alleles, resulting in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple sex determination alleles in M. mbenjii produce an interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation resulting in modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple sex determination alleles provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of multiple sex determination alleles in a species can result in the evolution of varied secondary sexual characteristics. © 2018 American Society of Microbiology. The retina is challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. Thus, Fe may be a therapeutic target for retinal diseases associated with bisretinoid accumulation. Copyright © 2015. Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are a unique group of predators because their tentacles are specialized for prey capture, and because they are the only group of predators that have evolved to use only nematocysts for prey capture. We studied the evolution of siphonophore tentacles, and found that they are highly specialized for prey capture. We also found that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The hominin hand is a complex of bones that has been the focus of intense study for the past century. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the evolution of the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also highlights the importance of the Turkana Basin as a key site for understanding the evolution of the hominin hand. (Read more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) that blocks cancer cell growth. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer with a high incidence of SHMT2 overexpression. We show that DLBCL cells are dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for DLBCL. This work provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer. It also provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in DLBCL. This work may lead to the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Deforestation is a major driver of biodiversity loss and climate change, but it is also a threat to people’s livelihoods and food security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets. We found that deforestation led to a reduction in fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our findings suggest that strategies to improve nutrition should consider the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new field of research, and we hope that our study will encourage others to use this approach to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets and other aspects of their livelihoods.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a global expansion of subsoil compaction risk, with 20% of arable land now at risk of subsoil compaction. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, highlighting the need for ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails. Our results have implications for the design of farm machinery and the management of agricultural practices. They also suggest that the expansion of agriculture may have had a negative impact on the environment of the past.
